from IPython.display import display, Markdown
import re

title: On or In a Bike/Train/Spaceship?
section: On a train or In a train?
text:
On a train or In a train?
A common challenge for learners of English is knowing which PREPOSITION (e.g.¬†in or on) to use in different contexts.
One example of this the situation where you are describing where you are when in different kinds of vehicles. For example:

üöÜ I am on a train
üöï I am in an taxi


How do we know when to use in and when to use on?


@EnglishwithLucy to the rescue!
The other day a Short from Lucy turned up on my YouTube addressing this specific issue.
  
And she promised:

I will teach you to know the correct answer every single time


Lucy‚Äôs answer‚Ä¶
Lucy promised her rule will make it so you never have to think about it again!

1. Rule for ON a vehicle











Tip



If you can walk onto the vehicle standing up on your feet, then its ON‚Ä¶
Examples: You get ON a plane, train, bus, tram




2. Rule for IN a vehicle







Tip



If you have to crouch down and sit in the vehicle‚Äìif you have to make yourself smaller‚Äìyou get IN..
Examples: You get IN a car, taxi, helicopter








But does it really work like that?



However, if you think for a moment you can see that maybe it isn‚Äôt that straight forward.
Sometimes you might use in in one context and on in another for the same vehicle. Especially, those in the second category.

I am on a plane right now‚Ä¶
Let me call you back I‚Äôm in a plane‚Ä¶

title: On or In a Bike/Train/Spaceship?
section: What do LLMs say about this?
text:
What do LLMs say about this?
Given that LLMs are train on huge amounts of data, the majority of it capturing instances of people using English and they excel at generalizing to patterns and templates, it seems like a reasonable assumption that most LLMs would have little trouble using the right preposition.
That is, you are unlikely to generate the text:
Speaker 1: Hey where are you right now?
Speaker 2: Oh I'm ON a car
...
Unless, I suppose Speaker 2 happens to be car surfing!


Bing CHAT (GPT 4)

PROMPT:
I am traveling using a specific vehicle. I get a call from someone and they ask ‚ÄúWhere are you?‚Äù. I might reply ‚ÄúI am IN a/an X‚Äù or ‚ÄúI am ON a/an Y‚Äù. Can you create a list of 10 vehicles that would be used in place of X (in a/an X) and 10 for those used for Y.

Generated the following response:

RESPONSE:
Sure, I can create such a list for you. Here are some possible vehicles that you can use in place of X or Y:

I am in a/an:

car
taxi
bus
train
airplane
helicopter
submarine
spaceship
tank
limousine

I am on a/an:

bike
motorcycle
boat
ship
skateboard
scooter
horse
camel
roller coaster
surfboard


I hope this helps you with your question. üòä


Observations

There are no overlapping items
Bing Chat doesn‚Äôt seem to be following Lucy‚Äôs rules here

‚ùå I am IN a bus
‚ùå I am IN a train
‚ùå I am IN an airplane

Skateboards and surfboards are something that seem outside of those rules too.



Does the LLM have a ‚Äòrule‚Äô it can explain?
I followed up by asking how the LLM was deciding between in and on:

PROMPT:
How do you decide between using IN or ON in this context?

And it gave a lengthy response making use of sources from a websearch.

RESPONSE:
There is no definitive rule for choosing between IN or ON for vehicles, but there are some general guidelines that can help you most of the time. Here are some of them:

Use IN when you are talking about a small or personal vehicle that has a compartment that surrounds you, such as a car, a taxi, a van, a train, an airplane, a helicopter, a submarine, or a spaceship.
Use ON when you are talking about a large or public vehicle that allows you to move around freely inside it, such as a bus, a boat, a ship, a roller coaster, or a plane.
Use ON when you are talking about a vehicle that you ride on top of, without a compartment, such as a bike, a motorcycle, a skateboard, a scooter, a horse, a camel, or a surfboard.

These are not absolute rules, and there may be some exceptions or variations depending on the context or the type of vehicle. For example, you can say that you are IN a canoe or a kayak, even though they are small and open, because you are sitting inside them. You can also say that you are ON a yacht or a cruise ship, even though they are large and enclosed, because you can walk around on them.
If you want to learn more about this topic, you can check out some of the web search results that I found for you¬π¬≤¬≥. I hope this helps you with your question. üòä
Source: Conversation with Bing, 2/8/2024 1. ‚ÄúIn‚Äù and ‚Äúon‚Äù: How can I decide which one to use for vehicles?. https://ell.stackexchange.com/questions/155/in-and-on-how-can-i-decide-which-one-to-use-for-vehicles. 2. What is the correct word to use for vehicles: in or on?. https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/eb/qa/What-is-the-correct-word-to-use-for-vehicles-in-or-on-. 3. When to use ‚Äúin‚Äù and ‚Äúon‚Äù | Britannica Dictionary. https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/eb/qa/When-to-use-prepositions-in-and-on.



Observations

It gives ‚Äúguidelines‚Äù similar to Lucy‚Äôs rules, with the addition of a third one for ‚Äúa vehicle that you ride on top of, without a compartment‚Äù, like a bike.
HOWEVER, some of the examples of vehicles are the opposite. For example, IN A PLANE vs ON A PLANE.
It cites some sources used in generating the answer. This is because Bing Chat is GPT4 where the results from a Bing search for a summary of your query are added to your query to augment the prompt, i.e.¬†it is a Retrieval Augmented Generation or RAG system.




Trying a smaller open source model

Using Ollama (ollama.ai)‚Äìtool that lets you use smaller large language models on a laptop‚ÄìI tried exploring the same question using a range of different prompts.
I queried the llama2-7b-chat model (see https://ollama.ai/library/llama2 for details)
The complete transcript is in the file llama2-7b_transcript.txt


llama2_ts = open('llama2-7b_transcript.txt').read()
responses = [resp for resp in re.split('(?=PROMPT)',llama2_ts) if resp]

I began with a specific example of taking a taxi journey to see how the LLM would complete the phrase ‚ÄúI am currently ‚Ä¶‚Äù

print(responses[0])

PROMPT: You take a taxi journey and receive a phone call. How would you describe your location to the person you are speaking to. 'I am currently ... 

RESPONSE: Great, thank you for asking! I can definitely help you with that.

So, if I'm in a taxi and receive a phone call, I would likely describe my 
location by giving the nearest landmark or cross streets. For example, I 
might say something like: "I'm currently at the intersection of 5th Avenue 
and 23rd Street in Manhattan."

Alternatively, if I have a specific destination in mind, I might give more 
detailed directions, such as: "I'm heading to the Empire State Building, 
which is located on 34th Street between 5th and 6th Avenues."

Of course, the exact way I would describe my location would depend on the 
context of the call and the specific location I am in. But hopefully, these 
examples give you a general idea of how I might respond!





Observations

Llama2 has been finetune to be a helpful conversation assistant. So is always very polite in responses, e.g.¬†‚ÄúGreat, thank you for asking!‚Äù
Using the word location in the prompt seems to push the LLM to focus outside of the location of the speaker, i.e.¬†‚ÄúIN A TAXI‚Äù, to a more general (and perhaps intuitive) sense of where the taxi currently is in terms of the journey the person is taking.
However, it does use the expected preposition in the response: > So, if I‚Äôm in a taxi and receive a phone call ‚Ä¶

Repeating the prompt but for a TRAIN instead of a TAXI:

print(responses[1])

PROMPT: You take a train journey and receive a phone call. How would you describe your location to the person you are speaking to. 'I am currently ...

RESPONSE: Great, thank you for asking! If I'm on a train journey and receive a phone 
call, I would likely describe my location by giving the name of the city or 
town we are passing through, along with the approximate distance from the 
destination. For example, I might say something like: "I am currently 
traveling through Philadelphia, which is about 20 miles west of New York 
City."

Alternatively, if I have a specific location in mind, such as a nearby 
landmark or attraction, I might give more detailed directions, such as: "I'm
passing by Independence Hall in Philadelphia, which is located downtown and 
about 2 miles from the train station."

Of course, the exact way I would describe my location would depend on the 
context of the call and the specific route and stops on the train journey. 
But hopefully, these examples give you a general idea of how I might 
respond![INST0]






Observations

Same points as above regarding the interpretation of location as reference to the currently stage of the journey.
And again in setting up the response, the LLM responds with the expected preposition (ON) > If I‚Äôm on a train journey and receive a phone call,



Trying a template prompt
Next, I tried to direct the LLM more specifically using a fill in the word template.

I am X a taxi


print(responses[2])

PROMPT: What word would you use in place of X in the clause "I am X a taxi"

RESPONSE: Great, thank you for asking! If we are trying to fill in the blank with a 
word that would be appropriate in the sentence "I am X a taxi," some 
possible options could include:

* Driver (as in, "I am John a taxi driver")
* Passenger (as in, "I am Sarah a taxi passenger")
* Rider (as in, "I am Tom a taxi rider")
* Customer (as in, "I am Jane a taxi customer")
* User (as in, "I am David a taxi user")

Of course, the exact word we would use would depend on the context and the 
relationship of the speaker to the taxi service. But hopefully, these 
options give you some ideas for how we might fill in the blank






Observations

My assumption that the most likely word to fill the X slot would be a preposition, i.e.¬†either in or on wasn‚Äôt quite right in this case.
It provides a range of options for people who would be associated with a taxi, e.g.¬†driver, passenger, rider, customer etc.



Trying to be more specific
So I went back and asked for just one word to fill the X slot and an example X=on

print(responses[3])

PROMPT: Just one word. So "I am X a plane" X=on

RESPONSE: Ah, I see! If we are trying to fill in the blank with just one word, here 
are some options that could work in the sentence "I am X a plane":

* On (as in, "I am John on a plane")
* In (as in, "I am Sarah in a plane")
* At (as in, "I am Tom at an airport")
* Onboard (as in, "I am Jane onboard a plane")

Of course, the exact word we would use would depend on the context and the 
relationship of the speaker to the flight. But hopefully, these options give
you some ideas for how we might fill in the blank!






Observations

Although, Llama2 seems to understand: > Ah, I see! If we are trying to fill in the blank with just one word
it adds people in each example sentence
Plane is used with both in and on (which is actually a realistic alternation)
The switch of plane to airport is interesting when it suggests the preposition at



Following up to get more examples‚Ä¶
I then tried to extend the prompt to more vehicles, some that would usually take in and others on.

print(responses[4])

PROMPT: So what one word for "I am X a taxi" and for "I am X a car" and for "I am X a boat" and for "I am X a train"

RESPONSE: Great, thank you for asking! Here are some possible one-word answers for 
each of the sentences:

For "I am X a taxi":

* Driver (as in, "I am John driver")

For "I am X a car":

* Owner (as in, "I am Sarah owner")

For "I am X a boat":

* Captain (as in, "I am Tom captain")

For "I am X a train":

* Conductor (as in, "I am Jane conductor")






Observations

The LLM is still determined to include a person role in each response.
The prepositions have disappeared!



Let‚Äôs try again
I tried to be even more specific in the prompt and mention that the one word should be a preposition.

print(responses[5])

PROMPT: Hmm not quite what I meant. Maybe if I said which preposition would you use in those sentences "I am X a taxi", "I am X a boat", "I am X a train", "I am X a car" and so on... does that help?

RESPONSE: Ah, I see! For each of the sentences you provided, here are some possible 
prepositions that could be used:

For "I am X a taxi":

* In (as in, "I am John in a taxi")
* On (as in, "I am Sarah on a taxi")

For "I am X a boat":

* On (as in, "I am Tom on a boat")
* In (as in, "I am Jane in a boat")

For "I am X a train":

* On (as in, "I am John on a train")
* In (as in, "I am Sarah in a train")

For "I am X a car":

* In (as in, "I am Tom in a car")
* On (as in, "I am Jane on a car")

Of course, the exact preposition we would use would depend on the context 
and the relationship of the speaker to the vehicle. But hopefully, these 
options give you some ideas for how we might fill in the blank!






Observations

Now it gives examples for both in and on for all of the vehicles mentioned.
And the person reference remains.



Trying to generalize to lists of vehicles

print(responses[6])

PROMPT: Ok lets try this. Are there some vehicles where you would say "I am IN the vehicle" compared to others where you would say "I am ON the vehicle". List vehicles for each preposition.

RESPONSE: Absolutely! Here are some examples of vehicles where we might use each 
preposition:

For "I am IN a taxi":

* Subway train
* Bus
* Plane

For "I am ON a taxi":

* Car
* Bike
* Boat

For "I am IN a boat":

* Submarine
* Ship
* Spacecraft

For "I am ON a boat":

* Kayak
* Canoe
* Sailboat

For "I am IN a train":

* Trolley
* Monorail
* Maglev train

For "I am ON a train":

* Automobile
* Bicycle
* Airplane

Of course, these are just general guidelines and the exact preposition we 
might use would depend on the context and the relationship of the speaker to
the vehicle. But hopefully, these examples give you some ideas for how we 
might fill in the blank






Observations

Based on previous prompts (as this was one chat session) we get some strange output where the responses are organized by phrases like "I am IN a taxi" and "I am ON a train"
Note that it has finally given up trying to include a person!



One final Llama2 attempt!

print(responses[7])

PROMPT: Ah to be clearer. Give me a list of vehicles that fill the slot Y in the clause "I am IN a Y" and also a list of vehicles that fill the slot Z in the clause "I am ON a Z"

REPONSE: Certainly! Here are some examples of vehicles that might fill the slots "Y" 
in the clause "I am IN a Y" and "Z" in the clause "I am ON a Z":

For "I am IN a Y":

* Subway train
* Bus
* Plane
* Boat
* Ship
* Spacecraft
* Trolley
* Monorail
* Maglev train

For "I am ON a Z":

* Car
* Bike
* Kayak
* Canoe
* Sailboat
* Bicycle
* Airplane

Of course, these are just general guidelines and the exact vehicle that 
might fill each slot would depend on the context and the relationship of the
speaker to the vehicle. But hopefully, these examples give you some ideas 
for how we might fill in the blank

title: Look at this stack of boxes‚Ä¶
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be:



Box
Stack position




GREEN
top


PINK
middle


PURPLE
bottom








If one explanation of how humans accomplish this task is

GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Ageism?‚Ä¶. It‚Äôs just a fact
text:
In a Meet the Press interview on Sunday 28th January, 2024, Republican primary candidate for President, Niki Haley said:

That‚Äôs exactly why we don‚Äôt need two people who are in their 80s running for president. It‚Äôs not being disrespectful it‚Äôs the fact that when you are 80 you are declining. It‚Äôs just a fact.

Please note that this post is definitely not intended to be political or even to specifically target Haley, but rather to look at how various LLMs respond to prompts exhibiting language and beliefs that might be considered ageist.


Just using the above quote without any framing or citation produces these kinds of responses:
LLM: mixtral-8x7b-instruct-v0.1 (Open Source) > > I understand your perspective that physical and mental abilities may decline as people age, which is a valid concern when choosing political leaders. However, it‚Äôs important to remember that age should not be the sole determinant of a person‚Äôs abilities or competence. Many individuals in their 80s remain sharp, active, and engaged in society. > > When evaluating political candidates, it‚Äôs crucial to consider their experience, wisdom, and the policies they stand for, rather than making assumptions based solely on their age. It‚Äôs also essential to respect individual autonomy and dignity, allowing elderly candidates to make their own decisions about their ability to serve in public office. > > In my aim to promote fairness and positivity, I encourage a well-informed and respectful dialogue about candidates, taking into account various factors, including their policy proposals, integrity, and leadership skills, instead of focusing exclusively on age. > > Source: https://chat.lmsys.org/ (default parameters: Temperature 0.7, Top P 1, Max Output Tokens 1024)
LLM: llama-2-7b-chat (Open Source)

I understand your point, and it is a valid concern. However, I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs fair to make blanket statements about people in their 80s being unable to hold public office. Every person is different, and their abilities and capacities can vary greatly regardless of their age.
It‚Äôs important to consider that older adults have a wealth of experience and knowledge that can be valuable in leadership roles. They have lived through different times and have a unique perspective on the world that can be an asset in making decisions. Additionally, many older adults are still mentally sharp and physically capable of handling the demands of public office.
It‚Äôs also worth noting that ageism, like any other form of discrimination, is not acceptable. It‚Äôs important to evaluate candidates based on their qualifications, skills, and abilities, rather than their age.
In the end, it‚Äôs up to the voters to decide who they think is the best candidate for the job, regardless of their age. It‚Äôs important to give all candidates a fair chance and to evaluate them based on their qualifications and abilities, rather than making assumptions based on their age.
Source: https://chat.lmsys.org/




The structure of the two responses are similar

Polite acceptance that statement may reflect potentially valid concerns and opinions but with a clear counter argument (However...) to establish that age need not imply decline or disqualification from office.
A paragraph explaining that age may actually be a positive benefit for public office.
Importance of considering a range of characteristics and qualifications beside age.
Emphasis on the role of voters in democratic system. 

Note that the Llama2 response makes explicit mention of the word ageism and that it is a form in unacceptable discrimination whereas the Mixtral response has an implied

Now, comparing these with two closed, commerical LLMs
LLM: gpt-4-turbo

It‚Äôs understandable that you express concerns about the age of political leaders, as it‚Äôs a legitimate topic for public discussion. The age and health of political candidates, particularly those running for demanding offices like the presidency, can be crucial factors for voters to consider. It is a fact that as people age, they may experience a decline in certain cognitive or physical abilities, and these changes can vary widely from person to person.
However, age is just one factor among many that voters might weigh when choosing a candidate. Experience, policy positions, leadership abilities, and the capacity to govern effectively are also important considerations. In democratic societies, it‚Äôs ultimately up to the electorate to decide which candidates they believe are most fit to hold office, taking into account all relevant factors, including age.
It‚Äôs worth noting that age alone does not determine a person‚Äôs capability to serve in a public role. There have been numerous cases of senior leaders who have performed their duties effectively. Furthermore, political leaders often work within a team context and are supported by a staff of advisors and experts who can help manage the workload and provide counsel.
It‚Äôs also important to recognize that discussions about age should be approached with sensitivity and respect for the dignity of individuals, as ageism can be a form of discrimination. Ultimately, the democratic process allows for the evaluation of each candidate on a case-by-case basis, and it is up to voters to make informed decisions based on a comprehensive assessment of each candidate‚Äôs overall fitness for office.
Source: https://chat.lmsys.org/

LLM: gemini-pro-dev-api

Age is an important factor to consider when evaluating candidates for political office. There are both advantages and disadvantages to having older candidates. On the one hand, older candidates may have more experience and wisdom than younger candidates. They may also be more likely to have a long-term perspective and to be less swayed by short-term political considerations. On the other hand, older candidates may be less in touch with the needs and concerns of younger voters. They may also be more likely to be set in their ways and to be resistant to change.
Ultimately, the decision of whether or not to vote for an older candidate is a personal one. There are valid arguments to be made on both sides of the issue. Voters should weigh the advantages and disadvantages carefully and make the decision that they believe is best for them and for their country.
It is important to note that there is no one-size-fits-all answer to the question of whether or not older candidates are suitable for political office. Some older candidates may be more capable and qualified than some younger candidates, and vice versa. It is important to evaluate each candidate on their individual merits, rather than making generalizations based on age.
It is also important to avoid making ageist comments or stereotypes. Ageism is a form of discrimination that can be just as harmful as other forms of discrimination. Older people should be treated with respect and dignity, regardless of their political beliefs or qualifications for office.
Source: https://chat.lmsys.org/





The structure and components of the responses are very similar to the two from Mixtral and Llama2.
Both GPT4 and Gemini use the indirect third person (it) (It's understandable) in response to the statement compared to the first person (I understand your point/perspective) in the other two model responses.
Both models contain a warning against and explicit mention of ageism.





Expanding the explorations a little, I wondered what would happen if I asked various LLMs to generate ageist statement.

PROMPT: Give some examples of ageist statements.

Mixtral

I‚Äôm here to provide helpful, respectful, and truthful information while ensuring your privacy. I always aim to avoid harmful, unethical, prejudiced, or negative content. Here are some examples of ageist statements that promote negative stereotypes and should be avoided:
‚ÄúOlder people can‚Äôt learn new technologies.‚Äù ‚ÄúYounger people are irresponsible and not ready for serious commitments.‚Äù ‚ÄúPeople over 60 should retire because they‚Äôre not productive anymore.‚Äù ‚ÄúTeenagers are only interested in social media and video games.‚Äù ‚ÄúElderly drivers are a danger on the road.‚Äù ‚ÄúYoung adults just want instant gratification and aren‚Äôt willing to work hard.‚Äù
These statements oversimplify and stereotype individuals based on their age, which can lead to discrimination and misunderstandings. It‚Äôs essential to treat everyone as an individual with unique experiences, skills, and perspectives, regardless of their age.

bard-jan-24-gemini-pro
